title: 113_hr5703
content: The "Protect and Preserve International Cultural Property Act" defines cultural property and identifies the appropriate congressional committees. It also includes findings and a statement of policy. Congress finds that protecting international cultural property is crucial for US cultural diplomacy, as it reflects respect for other cultures and the shared heritage of humanity. Instances of cultural property loss, damage, and destruction have occurred due to various factors like political instability, armed conflict, and natural disasters. Specific examples include the ransacking of museums in Egypt, looting of the Iraq Museum in Baghdad, and damage to medieval cities in Syria due to the civil war. These incidents have resulted in the irreversible destruction and loss of valuable ancient artifacts, leaving gaps in the historical record. In Syria, ongoing civil war has led to the shelling of medieval cities, damage to UNESCO World Heritage Sites, and looting of museums and archaeological sites. ISIS/ISIL in Iraq and Syria has destroyed cultural sites and artifacts, while in Mali, Ansar Dine destroyed tombs and shrines in Timbuktu. Afghanistan saw the Taliban decree the destruction of cultural heritage sites. In Afghanistan, the Taliban destroyed the Bamiyan Buddhas, leading to worldwide condemnation. In Cambodia, the Khmer Rouge systematically destroyed Buddhist temples, statues, and literature. In China, the Cultural Revolution resulted in the destruction of antiques and old Beijing. In Haiti, the 2010 earthquake destroyed art, artifacts, and archives, partially damaging the 17th century city of Jacmel. The 2004 Indian Ocean earthquake and tsunami caused massive loss of life and damaged cultural properties in eleven countries, including UNESCO World Heritage Sites like Mahabalipuram in India, Sun Temple of Koranak, and Old Town of Galle in Sri Lanka. The destruction of these sites represents an irreparable loss of humanity's cultural heritage. The United States Armed Forces have played a role in preserving cultural property through the establishment of the American Commission for the Protection and Salvage of Artistic and Historic Monuments in War Areas. The Monuments, Fine Arts, and Archives (MFAA) teams, known as the "Monuments Men," were formed by the military to secure and return art stolen by the Nazis during World War II. The U.S. Committee of the Blue Shield supports the protection of cultural property in armed conflicts and disasters. The United States policy is to protect and preserve international cultural property. The United States policy is to protect and preserve international cultural property at risk of destruction due to various factors, prevent the importation of pillaged cultural property, and enforce laws to prevent trafficking in stolen or looted cultural property. The White House Coordinator for International Cultural Property Protection is established under Section 4. The President appoints a White House Coordinator for International Cultural Property Protection to coordinate and promote efforts involving multiple Federal agencies, submit annual reports to congressional committees, provide policy recommendations, resolve interagency differences, and work with domestic and international actors. Various entities such as foreign governments, NGOs, museums, educational and research institutions, and the U.S. Committee of the Blue Shield collaborate to promote and protect international cultural property. SEC. 5. INFORMATION ON ACTIVITIES TO PROTECT INTERNATIONAL CULTURAL PROPERTY. The Secretary of State must provide information to the White House Coordinator on efforts to protect international cultural property, including activities under the Hague Convention and actions taken in conflicts involving the US. Additionally, details on protecting cultural property through other statutes, agreements, or policies must be reported. The Administrator of USAID and the Secretary of Defense must provide information to the White House Coordinator on efforts to protect international cultural property, including activities under international agreements and coordination with other organizations. The Department of Justice, in consultation with the Secretary of Homeland Security, must provide information on efforts to protect international cultural property, including actions taken to prevent damage during construction activities abroad. The Department of Justice must provide information on statutes, regulations, and actions taken to protect international cultural property, including efforts to prevent trafficking and ensure consistent application of law. Federal agencies can partner with the Smithsonian Institution for international cultural property protection activities, allowing personnel from the Smithsonian to assist in such efforts. Agencies are authorized to cover the salaries and expenses of Smithsonian personnel for this purpose, including support for military, diplomatic, and law enforcement missions. The Secretary of State is authorized to make grants for international cultural property protection activities in areas at risk of destruction. Additionally, emergency protection for Syrian cultural property is provided for. The President will apply import restrictions to archaeological or ethnological material of Syria as if Syria were a State Party to the Convention on the Cultural Property Implementation Act. The restrictions will take effect within 60 days of the enactment of this Act, and apply to cultural property unlawfully removed from Syria after August 18, 2011. The term "State Party" in this context refers to the definition provided in section 302 of the Convention on the Cultural Property Implementation Act.
